slides.title: What is Programming?
slides.content:
# Talking to Machines üó£Ô∏è

Writing instructions for a computer to execute.
- Code is written in high-level languages (Python, Java, Dart).
- Compiled/Interpreted into machine code (0s and 1s).

slides.title: Variables
slides.content:
# Boxes üì¶

Named storage for data.
- **Integer**: Whole numbers (5).
- **Float/Double**: Decimals (3.14).
- **String**: Text ("Hello").
- **Boolean**: True/False.

slides.title: Control Flow: Conditionals
slides.content:
# Fork in Road üç¥

Making decisions.
```python
if hungry:
  eat()
else:
  sleep()
```

slides.title: Control Flow: Loops
slides.content:
# Repeat üîÅ

Doing things many times.
- **For Loop**: Repeat N times.
- **While Loop**: Repeat until condition is false.
"Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY)" principle.

slides.title: Functions
slides.content:
# Reusable Tools üî®

A block of code that performs a specific task.
- Input: Arguments.
- Output: Return value.
Allows breaking big problems into small pieces.

slides.title: Loop Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which loop is best when you know exactly how many times you want to repeat?

slides.title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
slides.content:
# Class & Objects üèóÔ∏è

Modeling code on real world things.
- **Class**: Blueprint (Car).
- **Object**: Instance (My Red Toyota).
- **Attributes**: Variables (Color, Speed).
- **Methods**: Functions (Drive, Stop).

slides.title: Inheritance
slides.content:
# Passing Down üß¨

Child class takes features from Parent class.
- Parent: `Animal` (has `eat`).
- Child: `Dog` (inherits `eat`, adds `bark`).
Code reuse!

slides.title: Encapsulation
slides.content:
# Secret Sauce ü•´

Hiding internal details.
- Public Interface: Buttons you can press.
- Private Data: Wiring you shouldn't touch.
Protects code from breaking.

slides.title: Polymorphism
slides.content:
# Many Forms üé≠

Different objects responding to same function call differently.
`Animal.speak()`
- Dog: "Woof"
- Cat: "Meow"

slides.title: Debugging
slides.content:
# Squashing Bugs üêõ

Fixing errors in logic or syntax.
- **Syntax Error**: Typo (Computer doesn't understand).
- **Logic Error**: Code runs, but does wrong thing.
- Print statements vary helpful.

slides.title: OOP Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: In OOP, a 'Blueprint' for creating objects is called a:

slides.title: Compilers vs Interpreters
slides.content:
# Translation üó£Ô∏è

- **Compiler** (C++): Translates entire code to machine code at once. Runs fast.
- **Interpreter** (Python): Translates line-by-line. Easier to test.

slides.title: Version Control
slides.content:
# Time Machine üï∞Ô∏è

Git / GitHub.
- Tracking changes to code.
- Allows returning to previous versions.
- Essential for teams working together.

slides.title: APIs
slides.content:
# Waiter ü§µ

Application Programming Interface.
- Way for two programs to talk.
- You ask API for "Weather", it returns data.
You don't need to know *how* it got the weather.

slides.title: Functional Programming
slides.content:
# Pure Logic üß†

Paradigm treating computation as math functions.
- No changing state (Immutability).
- Fewer bugs, easy to parallelize.
- Examples: Haskell, Lisp.

slides.title: Libraries and Frameworks
slides.content:
# Don't Reinvent Wheel üé°

- **Library**: Collection of functions you call (jQuery).
- **Framework**: Structure calling your code (Flutter, React).

slides.title: Clean Code
slides.content:
# Readability üìñ

Writing code for humans, not just machines.
- Good variable names.
- Comments where needed.
- Consistent formatting.

slides.title: Progamming Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Variables** store data.
- **Loops/Conditions** control flow.
- **OOP** organizes large code.
- Programming is solving puzzles with logic.
